issue.title: Feature Request: OCI Artefact support
issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue please visit https://docs.dapr.io/operations/support/support-security-issues -->

## In what area(s)?

<!-- Remove the '> ' to select -->

> /area runtime

> /area operator

> /area placement

> /area docs

/area test-and-release

## Describe the feature

Hello,

Before submitting a PR, I'd like to check if the team is open to releasing the Helm chart as an OCI artifact as well.

I've recently implemented this for the Argo CD helm-charts, which can be seen here: https://github.com/argoproj/argo-helm/pull/2209. The changes to the workflow were quite minimal.

Releasing the dapr charts as an OCI artifact would simplify distribution, especially within enterprise settings that use systems like Artifactory or Harbor.

<!-- Please also discuss possible business value -->

## Release Note
<!-- How should this new feature be announced in our release notes? It can be populated later. -->
<!-- Keep it as a single line. Examples: -->

<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **ADD** New feature in Dapr. -->
<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **FIX** Bug in runtime. -->
<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **UPDATE** Runtime dependency. -->

RELEASE NOTE:

issue.title: Dapr Rabbitmq pubsub consumer issue
issue.body:
## In what area(s)?

> /area runtime

## What version of Dapr?

> 1.11.0

## Expected Behavior

Problem on pubsub component.
I am publishing 50 thousand record. It should consume 50 thousand record.

I am using rabbit-mq as pubsub component. I am publishing 50 thousand record which only change 1 property value. It should consume all 50 thousand records


## Actual Behavior
It consumes all records. I can see on queue at RabbitMq dashboard (ready record is 0 at the end of consumes). But on my counter there seems dissappear more than 500 records. 


## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

I have 4 .net 7 project for reproduce. 

Pubsub_RabbitMq_Sub_Sample
Pubsub_RabbitMq_Pub_Sample
Pubsub_Dapr_Sub_Sample
Pubsub_Dapr_Pub_Sample

RabbitMq Pub - RabbitMq Sub -> No problem
Dapr Pub - RabbitMq Sub (enableRawPayload) -> No problem
Dapr Pub - Dapr Sub -> Issue appearing

Note: enableRawPayload doesn't matter. 

## Release Note
RELEASE NOTE: **FIX** Pubsub consumer messages dissappear

[Pubsub_RabbitMq_Pub_Sample.txt](https://github.com/dapr/dapr/files/12868436/Pubsub_RabbitMq_Pub_Sample.txt)
[Pubsub_RabbitMq_Sub_Sample.txt](https://github.com/dapr/dapr/files/12868437/Pubsub_RabbitMq_Sub_Sample.txt)
[Pubsub_Dapr_Pub_Sample.txt](https://github.com/dapr/dapr/files/12868438/Pubsub_Dapr_Pub_Sample.txt)
[Pubsub_Dapr_Sub_Sample.txt](https://github.com/dapr/dapr/files/12868439/Pubsub_Dapr_Sub_Sample.txt)

comment.body: @hmeniz Hi, I do not know .net much, the first idea that comes to my mind may be due to concurrency. Can you please check if your sub sample app uses an atomic counter or try to set `dapr.io/app-max-concurrency: "1"` annotation and have a retry? For more information on how to set app max concurrency to 1: https://docs.dapr.io/operations/configuration/control-concurrency/

pull_request.title: Integration: Adds `-focus` CLI flag
pull_request.body:
Adds a `-focus` CLI flag to the integration test runner. This flag allows the user to specify a regex to filter the tests that are run.

This is to allow easier focusing on a specific test when debugging or developing a new test.

Even if `-focus` is enabled, binaries will always be built.

``` bash
go test -v -race -tags integration ./tests/integration -focus sentry
go test -v -race -tags integration ./tests/integration -test.skip Test_Integration/sentry/validator/jwks -focus sentry
```

commits.message:
Tiny tweaks in `utils` (#7096)

* Small tweaks in `utils`

1. Moved Kubernetes functions to a more specific `kubernetes.go` file (without code changes)
2. Small perf improvements for `Filter`, about 8% faster (305.5ns/op -> 281.5ns/op)
3. Even smaller perf improvement for IsTruthy (bigger improvement on larger strings)

Signed-off-by: ItalyPaleAle <43508+ItalyPaleAle@users.noreply.github.com>

issue.title: Support priorityClass assignment in Helm charts
issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue please visit https://docs.dapr.io/operations/support/support-security-issues -->

## In what area(s)?

<!-- Remove the '> ' to select -->

> /area runtime

> /area operator

> /area placement

> /area docs

> /area test-and-release

## Describe the feature

It would be great to support priorityClass assignments for all helm charts.  When running in kubernetes, there are times when our clusters are undergoing node replacement, clusters are facing capacity constraints, or workloads are recovering from a catastrophic event -- we rely heavily on various priority class assignments to ensure certain workloads are prioritized.  Since dapr is required for nominal functionality, it's imperative that dapr pods are scheduled with a high priority and are able to preempt other pods -- if dapr's sidecar-injection isn't available nothing is operational.

## Release Note
<!-- How should this new feature be announced in our release notes? It can be populated later. -->
<!-- Keep it as a single line. Examples: -->

<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **ADD** New feature in Dapr. -->
<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **FIX** Bug in runtime. -->
<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **UPDATE** Runtime dependency. -->

RELEASE NOTE:

pull_request.title: [Workflow] Make workflow engine configurable (and other improvements)
pull_request.body:
# Description

Until now, there was no way to configure the workflow engine. Some values, such as maximum concurrency thresholds, had been hardcoded. With this PR, however, it's now possible to configure the workflow engine. In particular, this PR enables configuring the maximum workflow and activity execution concurrency (defaults to 100, as it did previously).

This PR also contains other misc. fixes and code refactoring. Specifically:

- Reorganized some of the workflow and activity configuration to make it more cleanly separated from workflow engine configuration.
- Added some additional debug logging based on issues I had while debugging my changes.
- Updated workflow test code to output debug logs (previously was only outputting info logs)

I've added comments to the PR directly to help explain some of the specific changes.

## Issue reference

https://github.com/dapr/dapr/issues/7089

## Checklist

* [x] Code compiles correctly
* [x] Created/updated tests
* [x] Unit tests passing
* [ ] End-to-end tests passing
* [x] Extended the documentation / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: https://github.com/dapr/docs/pull/3844
* [ ] ~Specification has been updated / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: dapr/docs#_[issue number]~
* [ ] ~Provided sample for the feature / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: dapr/docs#_[issue number]~

issue.title: Propagate content type properties in state store requests
issue.body:
# Description

- Updates the gRPC state store (bulk) set behavior to propagate any content type set in the metadata to the request content type property.
- Updates the HTTP state store (bulk) set behavior to:
   - Propagate any content type set in the metadata to the request content type property
   - Propagate any set content type property to the metadata
   - If both content type properties are set, overwrites the metadata property with the request property
- Updates the state store pluggable component adaptor to change the content type properties if it serializes a value to a JSON-formatted encoded string. This enables pluggable components the ability to differentiate between opaque arrays and implicitly JSON-based values.  (Built-in components can be passed both opaque arrays and object instances, whereas pluggable components can be passed only opaque arrays.)

## Issue reference

Please reference the issue this PR will close: #6208 

## Checklist

Please make sure you've  completed the relevant tasks for this PR, out of the following list:

* [x] Code compiles correctly
* [x] Created/updated tests
* [x] Unit tests passing
* [ ] End-to-end tests passing
* [ ] Extended the documentation / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: dapr/docs#_[issue number]_
* [ ] Specification has been updated / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: dapr/docs#_[issue number]_
* [ ] Provided sample for the feature / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: dapr/docs#_[issue number]_

issue.title: Enhance Logging for Workflow
issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue please visit https://docs.dapr.io/operations/support/support-security-issues -->

## In what area(s)?

<!-- Remove the '> ' to select -->

/area runtime

> /area operator

> /area placement

> /area docs

> /area test-and-release

## Describe the feature
<!-- Please also discuss possible business value -->
Currently, it is rather difficult to diagnose an issue that occurs when a user is using dapr workflow, and due to dapr workflow being a new feature, issues occur more frequently than hoped. By adding in additional logging, diagnosing the issue will be a much easier process. I am proposing the following logs to be added to the runtime:

1. Creation of a Workflow
`c.logger.Infof("Created workflow %s with instanceID '%s'", <workflowName>, <instanceID>)`
- Include the Instance ID for the workflow
- Include the name of the workflow
2. Scheduling of an Activity
`c.logger.Infof("Scheduling activity '%s' for workflow %s with instanceID %s", <activityName>, <workflowName>, <instanceID>)`
- Include the name of the activity
- Include the name of the workflow
- Include the instanceID for the workflow
3. Execution of an Activity
`c.logger.Infof("Executing activity '%s' for workflow %s with instanceID %s", <activityName>, <workflowName>, <instanceID>)`
- Include the name of the activity
- Include the name of the workflow
- Include the instanceID for the workflow
4. Completion of an Activity
`c.logger.Infof("Activity '%s' completed with status: '%s' for workflow %s with instanceID %s", <activityName>, <activityStatus>, <workflowName>, <instanceID>)`
- Include the name of the activity
- Include the name of the workflow
- Include the instanceID for the workflow
- Include the status of the activity (pass/fail)
5. Completion of a Workflow
`c.logger.Infof("Workflow %s with instanceID %s completed with status: '%s'", <workflowName>, <instanceID>, <workflowStatus>)`
- Include the Instance ID for the workflow
- Include the name of the workflow
- Include the status of the workflow (pass/fail)

In addition to the proposed logs for the runtime, I am also proposing that we add logs to the various SDKs which will provide information that the runtime does not have access to. These logs are as follows:

1. Registration of a Workflow
`log("Workflow <workflowName> has been successfully registered")`
- Include the name of the workflow
2. Registration of an Activity
`log("Activity <activityName> has been successfully registered to workflow <workflowName>")`
- Include the name of the activity
- Include the parent workflow of the activity

## Additional Thoughts
1. Timestamps could also be added to the beginning of the various log statements to help create a timeline for the workflow execution. One downside would be that the logs may get too cluttered.
2. The current proposal is to have the log statements as a level of "info". Again, to avoid cluttering the output, the log level could (and quite possibly should) be toned down to "debug"
4. If/when more logs are added to the various SDKs, we should first determine if they can be added to the runtime, and if so, add them there. If not, we must ensure that the logs across all SKDKs are of a consistent format.
## Release Note
<!-- How should this new feature be announced in our release notes? It can be populated later. -->
<!-- Keep it as a single line. Examples: -->

<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **ADD** New feature in Dapr. -->
<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **FIX** Bug in runtime. -->
<!-- RELEASE NOTE: **UPDATE** Runtime dependency. -->

RELEASE NOTE:

comment.body:
Can I make a super minor suggestion that you tweak the message format for 4 and 5 (and the registration messages) so that they follow the same pattern as 1, 2 3.

i.e. `Activity '%s' completed with status: '%s' for workflow %s with instanceID %s"`
becomes 
`Activity completed... `

`Workflow %s with instanceID %s completed with status: '%s'", <workflowName>, <instanceID>, <workflowStatus>`
becomes
`Workflow completed...`

This format helps when doing searches across logs as I can easily search for the phrase `Workflow completed` rather than searching for `workflow` and then filtering that list of results further by searching for `completed` (which still may give too many unwanted matches)

issue.title: Allow Sidecar Injector to Treat Resources in Dapr-system Namespace as Global and Fix Injection for StatefulSets
issue.body:
With the update to Dapr v1.12, we noticed a change in behavior regarding how components are injected across different namespaces in a Kubernetes environment. Prior to this update, we were able to define a "global" component within the `dapr-system` namespace and have that component injected into pods across different namespaces. Post the v1.12 update, the components defined in the `dapr-system` namespace are no longer globally injected and instead, components have to be defined within the specific app namespace.

Additionally, we observed that if the pod type is a `StatefulSet`, Dapr does not inject the component. This presents an additional issue that needs to be addressed.

Proposal:

To provide more flexibility for users and to avoid repetitive component definitions across namespaces, it's proposed to:

1. Introduce an opt-in behavior where the sidecar injector can treat resources defined in the `dapr-system` namespace as global.
2. This could potentially be achieved via a new command-line flag in the sidecar injector.
3. Address the issue of component injection into pods of type `StatefulSet` to ensure they can properly receive components.

This feature will enable users who have multiple apps running in different namespaces to leverage a global component definition, thereby streamlining the setup process and minimizing redundancy.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Define a component in the `dapr-system` namespace.
2. Deploy an application in a different namespace.
3. Observe that the component from `dapr-system` is not injected into the new application's pods.
4. Deploy a `StatefulSet` and observe the component isn't injected.

Expected Behavior:

Components defined in the `dapr-system` namespace should be available (injected) to pods in other namespaces when the proposed flag/setting is enabled. Furthermore, `StatefulSets` should correctly receive component injections.

Release Note:

Feature: Introduced a flag in the sidecar injector to allow resources in the `dapr-system` namespace to be treated as global across all namespaces. Fixed component injection for `StatefulSets`.

issue.title: [Workflow] Support for workflow ID reuse policies
issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue please visit https://docs.dapr.io/operations/support/support-security-issues -->

## In what area(s)?

> /area runtime

## Describe the feature

This is a continuation of a discussion [here](https://github.com/dapr/dapr/issues/6434). The idea is simplify the creation and re-creation of workflows that have a well-known workflow ID.

When scheduling the creation of a new workflow instance, the following options should be available (taken from the proposal by @clintsinger):

- `TerminateIfExists` - Terminates any existing workflows with the same instance ID and then schedules a new instance as one atomic action, similar to on-demand ContinueAsNew.
- `SkipIfExists` - If there is an existing workflow already scheduled, then the scheduler does nothing.
- `ThrowIfExists` - If there is an existing workflow then the scheduler throws an exception (this is the current behavior).

As an optional extension of this, we can consider exposing an "Execution ID" or "Generation ID" property to the workflow which can help distinguish different instantiations of the given workflow instance ID. The Durable Task Framework has this concept already (it's an auto-generated UUID) but we don't currently surface it anywhere.

## Release Note

RELEASE NOTE: **ADD** Workflow creation policy options.

comment.body: Based on the proposal above, this would come into play only when using the (default) `ThrowIfExists` policy. I agree that we need to have a better exception handling story than this.

issue.title: Failed to get [<key>] from Configuration store <configstorename>: context deadline exceeded
issue.body:
# BUG REPORT: Failed to get [`<key>`] from Configuration store `<configstorename>`: context deadline exceeded

### Issue description
I'm trying to use DAPR with ACA. I created a lean example that attempts to access DAPR through both URL and SDK to retrieve configuration settings. It works on my local machine without any issues, but on Azure, it gives a context deadline exceeded error with the SDK and a 500 error with the URL.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create Azure App Configuration
0. Create Azure Container App
0. Define AAC in ACA DAPR component
0. Enable DAPR on ACA
0. Deploy an image to ACA

You can use the same [sample project](https://github.com/cilerler/test-20231018) I use.

> [!NOTE]  
> The following steps are optional but allow you to easily try out the repository. The workflow file building the image and updating the container image on Azure Container App.

Update the GitHub repository settings to deploy it via the action.

1. Set `CONTAINER_APP_NAME_PREFIX` action variable e.g. `HelloDapr`
2. Set `AZURE_CONTAINERREGISTRY` action secret e.g. `<YOURREGISTRY>.azurecr.io`
3. Set `AZURE_CREDENTIALS` action secret e.g.

    ```json
    {
	    "clientId": "<GUID>",
	    "clientSecret": "<SECRET>",
	    "subscriptionId": "<GUID>",
	    "tenantId": "<GUID>"
    }
    ```

## EXPECTED BEHAVIOR

It should retrieve the key via HTTP and GRPC.

## ACTUAL BEHAVIOR

- HTTP returns `500 (Internal Server Error)`
- GRPS returns `context deadline exceeded`


## LOGS

### CONSOLE

#### APP

```log

2023-10-21T19:35:05.028070936Z warn: Microsoft.AspNetCore.DataProtection.KeyManagement.XmlKeyManager[35]
2023-10-21T19:35:05.028088872Z       No XML encryptor configured. Key {d040c521-ec88-4345-b036-fe00e1b8527c} may be persisted to storage in unencrypted form.
2023-10-21T19:35:05.129410863Z info: Microsoft.Hosting.Lifetime[14]
2023-10-21T19:35:05.129443288Z       Now listening on: http://[::]:80
2023-10-21T19:35:05.130630039Z info: Microsoft.Hosting.Lifetime[0]
```

issue.title: Failed to get [<key>] from Configuration store <configstorename>: context deadline exceeded
issue.body:
# BUG REPORT: Failed to get [`<key>`] from Configuration store `<configstorename>`: context deadline exceeded

### Issue description
I'm trying to use DAPR with ACA. I created a lean example that attempts to access DAPR through both URL and SDK to retrieve configuration settings. It works on my local machine without any issues, but on Azure, it gives a context deadline exceeded error with the SDK and a 500 error with the URL.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create Azure App Configuration
0. Create Azure Container App
0. Define AAC in ACA DAPR component
0. Enable DAPR on ACA
0. Deploy an image to ACA

You can use the same [sample project](https://github.com/cilerler/test-20231018) I use.

> [!NOTE]  
> The following steps are optional but allow you to easily try out the repository. The workflow file building the image and updating the container image on Azure Container App.

Update the GitHub repository settings to deploy it via the action.

1. Set `CONTAINER_APP_NAME_PREFIX` action variable e.g. `HelloDapr`
2. Set `AZURE_CONTAINERREGISTRY` action secret e.g. `<YOURREGISTRY>.azurecr.io`
3. Set `AZURE_CREDENTIALS` action secret e.g.

    ```json
    {
	    "clientId": "<GUID>",
	    "clientSecret": "<SECRET>",
	    "subscriptionId": "<GUID>",
	    "tenantId": "<GUID>"
    }
    ```

## EXPECTED BEHAVIOR

It should retrieve the key via HTTP and GRPC.

## ACTUAL BEHAVIOR

- HTTP returns `500 (Internal Server Error)`
- GRPS returns `context deadline exceeded`


## LOGS

### CONSOLE

#### APP


comment.body: Closing this issue in favor of https://github.com/microsoft/azure-container-apps/issues/950.

issue.title: [Workflow] Support for workflow ID reuse policies
issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue please visit https://docs.dapr.io/operations/support/support-security-issues -->

## In what area(s)?

> /area runtime

## Describe the feature

This is a continuation of a discussion [here](https://github.com/dapr/dapr/issues/6434). The idea is simplify the creation and re-creation of workflows that have a well-known workflow ID.

When scheduling the creation of a new workflow instance, the following options should be available (taken from the proposal by @clintsinger):

- `TerminateIfExists` - Terminates any existing workflows with the same instance ID and then schedules a new instance as one atomic action, similar to on-demand ContinueAsNew.
- `SkipIfExists` - If there is an existing workflow already scheduled, then the scheduler does nothing.
- `ThrowIfExists` - If there is an existing workflow then the scheduler throws an exception (this is the current behavior).

As an optional extension of this, we can consider exposing an "Execution ID" or "Generation ID" property to the workflow which can help distinguish different instantiations of the given workflow instance ID. The Durable Task Framework has this concept already (it's an auto-generated UUID) but we don't currently surface it anywhere.

## Release Note

RELEASE NOTE: **ADD** Workflow creation policy options.

comment.body:
While we're on the subject of scheduling workflows, @cgillum I raised some feedback a while back that it would be useful to improve the DevEx for the scenario when trying to start a workflow when that workflow is already running. 

Right now, it throws an Exception, Ideally i'd prefer it not to throw, as it's not necessarily an exceptional circumstance, it's entirely use-case specific.

However, in the spirit of being pragmatic, if an Exception must remain, it would be nice to have it throw a specific exception, rather than relying on matching a vague/ambiguous string prefix, which could change!

this is what I do right now :

```c#
try
{
    result = await workflowClient.ScheduleNewWorkflowAsync(
        name: nameof(SagaWorkflow),
        instanceId: workflowId,
        input: orderInfo);
}
catch(Grpc.Core.RpcException ex) when (ex.StatusCode == Grpc.Core.StatusCode.Unknown && ex.Status.Detail.StartsWith("an active workflow with ID"))
{
    ...
}
```

comment.diff_hunk:

pull_request.title: [Workflow] Make workflow engine configurable (and other improvements)
pull_request.body:
# Description

Until now, there was no way to configure the workflow engine. Some values, such as maximum concurrency thresholds, had been hardcoded. With this PR, however, it's now possible to configure the workflow engine. In particular, this PR enables configuring the maximum workflow and activity execution concurrency (defaults to 100, as it did previously).

This PR also contains other misc. fixes and code refactoring. Specifically:

- Reorganized some of the workflow and activity configuration to make it more cleanly separated from workflow engine configuration.
- Added some additional debug logging based on issues I had while debugging my changes.
- Updated workflow test code to output debug logs (previously was only outputting info logs)

I've added comments to the PR directly to help explain some of the specific changes.

## Issue reference

https://github.com/dapr/dapr/issues/7089

## Checklist

* [x] Code compiles correctly
* [x] Created/updated tests
* [x] Unit tests passing
* [ ] End-to-end tests passing
* [x] Extended the documentation / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: https://github.com/dapr/docs/pull/3844
* [ ] ~Specification has been updated / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: dapr/docs#_[issue number]~
* [ ] ~Provided sample for the feature / Created issue in the https://github.com/dapr/docs/ repo: dapr/docs#_[issue number]~

issue.title: [Workflow] Support for workflow ID reuse policies
issue.body:
<!-- If you need to report a security issue please visit https://docs.dapr.io/operations/support/support-security-issues -->

## In what area(s)?

> /area runtime

## Describe the feature

This is a continuation of a discussion [here](https://github.com/dapr/dapr/issues/6434). The idea is simplify the creation and re-creation of workflows that have a well-known workflow ID.

When scheduling the creation of a new workflow instance, the following options should be available (taken from the proposal by @clintsinger):

- `TerminateIfExists` - Terminates any existing workflows with the same instance ID and then schedules a new instance as one atomic action, similar to on-demand ContinueAsNew.
- `SkipIfExists` - If there is an existing workflow already scheduled, then the scheduler does nothing.
- `ThrowIfExists` - If there is an existing workflow then the scheduler throws an exception (this is the current behavior).

As an optional extension of this, we can consider exposing an "Execution ID" or "Generation ID" property to the workflow which can help distinguish different instantiations of the given workflow instance ID. The Durable Task Framework has this concept already (it's an auto-generated UUID) but we don't currently surface it anywhere.

## Release Note

RELEASE NOTE: **ADD** Workflow creation policy options.

issue.title: Workflow/Actors: Distributed batch processing with custom partitioning
issue.body:
# In what area(s)?

/area runtime

/area operator

> /area placement

> /area docs

> /area test-and-release

## Describe the feature
Sometimes actions on flows are more efficient / faster to do as a batch, rather than massively parallel, so I'm looking for an elegant & reliable way to "fan-in" several workflow instances; or perhaps be able to write a special "batch handling" method on the dapr actor, which provides a partitioning value.

This would be especially handy in areas where you need to bulk import / enrich data / etc with a third party service, such as  or submit.

Theoretical usage (with Actor)

Client:
```C#
// Send single bit of data to a pre-partitioned actor
var id = LoanActorId.Create(item.Address.State); // <-- partition by state
var proxy = Factory.CreateActorProxy<IGeoLookup>(id, "GeoLookup");
item.Address.LatLon = await proxy.ProcessInBatch(item);
```

Actor:
```C#
[BatchReceive(maxItems: 10, batchWindowTimeoutMs: 100)]
async Task<Dictionary<string, LatLon>> ProcessInBatch(ItemType[] item)
{
    // ... Send as batch to geocoding API... 
   // i.e. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/maps/search/get-search-address-batch?tabs=HTTP#post-body-for-batch-request
}
```

Obviously this glosses over the finer points, but the ultimate goal is to abstract away the complexity of trying to do something like this.

comment.body:
> I wasn't aware of the dapr workflow batching, but yes I am mainly interested in actors. I assumed workflows were built on top of actors.

Yes, workflows are built on top of actors, but it's an internal implementation detail with a completely separate programming model. Indeed, it sounds like your feature request is specific to the Dapr Actors programming model.

issue.title: Workflow/Actors: Distributed batch processing with custom partitioning
issue.body:
# In what area(s)?

/area runtime

/area operator

> /area placement

> /area docs

> /area test-and-release

## Describe the feature
Sometimes actions on flows are more efficient / faster to do as a batch, rather than massively parallel, so I'm looking for an elegant & reliable way to "fan-in" several workflow instances; or perhaps be able to write a special "batch handling" method on the dapr actor, which provides a partitioning value.

This would be especially handy in areas where you need to bulk import / enrich data / etc with a third party service, such as  or submit.

Theoretical usage (with Actor)

Client:
```C#
// Send single bit of data to a pre-partitioned actor
var id = LoanActorId.Create(item.Address.State); // <-- partition by state
```


comment.body:
Hi @onionhammer. I see that you mentioned workflow in this issue but your suggestion seems to mostly be about actors. Did you have any scenarios in mind for [Dapr Workflow](https://docs.dapr.io/developing-applications/building-blocks/workflow/workflow-overview/) related to batching or are you mostly interested in batching support for actors?

Dapr workflows give you some primitives that make it easy to do batching already. For example, some users will use workflows as aggregators to collect a set of events (using [wait-for-external-event](https://docs.dapr.io/developing-applications/building-blocks/workflow/workflow-features-concepts/#external-events) workflow APIs) and then push them as a single batch to some external API via an activity. I'm curious to know if this might help with your use case.

pull_request.title: Integration: Only write process logs on failure
pull_request.body: PR updates the integration test io writer to by default, only write the exec process logs on test failure. This is in an effort to reduce the amount of IO done by the test runners. If a test fails, the processes logs will be output at the end. Logs can be enabled for all tests by setting the `DAPR_INTEGRATION_LOGS` environment variable to `true`.
